text: [Music]
hello comrades and welcome back to
today's video session i'm still thomas
still one of the fantastic ielts
teachers here at lango learning system
today we're going to welcome the most
beautiful season of the year spring
what we can observe most in this season
is that the flowers are fully in bloom
and how excited and alive people feel
during this vibrant time of year today
we're going to learn about some idioms
that contain flowers to enable us to
discuss spring using more dynamic and
engaging language
the first expression is
no bed of roses the expression bed of
roses refers to a very agreeable
situation
conversely no bed of roses indicates
something that's difficult
the current developments of the virus
are certainly no bed of roses for the
authorities to try and manage the next
phrase relates to the violet flower it's
shrinking violet
shrinking means to get smaller and
withered so this phrase indicates a shy
person who doesn't dare to raise their
voice and express their opinions
the teacher pays special attention to
the girl sitting in the corner who
doesn't speak to anyone she is a real
shrinking violet and the teacher is
trying to raise her confidence levels
when it comes to an unanticipated
situation we might say oopsie daisy
this expression indicates surprise ups
are daisy i just dropped all of the exam
papers on the floor next up we have an
interesting idiom that relates to one of
the most fragile flowers this is bouquet
of orchids if somebody deserves a
bouquet of orchids they've done
something worthy of praise in the
running competition the winner will be
given a bouquet of orchids now we come
to a familiar and very pretty flower we
have the idiom to gild the lily as you
know the lily already has natural beauty
but when you guild the lily you decorate
something that was already covered in
many ornaments you've gone too far or
added too much adding the cravat to the
suit was really gilding the lily he
looks like a peacock with all those
accessories carrying a different meaning
to the others we've got an idiom
containing daisies to push up the
daisies this means that someone has
passed away every year i celebrate the
fact that my worst enemy is pushing up
the daisies with a glass of wine and a
fat cigar when there's a variety of
something in the garden we can know that
it's not special at all so we can use
the phrase
garden variety this means ordinary not
special the film has been assessed as
being of the garden variety in other
words it's pretty mediocre the final
idiom for today's session is come up
roses or coming up roses this means to
gain a positive result after a long time
being unemployed he found a job which
relates to his major at university in
the end everything came up roses for him
i really hope that you found this
session helpful in preparing you for
your ielts test if you want to sign up
for ielts courses here at lango please
click on the link below our ielts
courses are designed with you in mind to
cater to your individual needs by
providing personalized learning pathways
remember to like and subscribe and don't
forget to hit that bell button to get
notifications of our latest video
uploads once again i've been thomas at
lango learning system and i'm pretty
sure i'll see you again bye stay safe
